diagnosis.final_diagnosis: CYP24A1 mutation causing chronic hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria
diagnosis.diagnostic_reasoning: The diagnosis was supported by modern biochemical and genetic tools, including evidence of elevated calcium absorption, low levels of 24,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, very high serum levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, and genetic analysis revealing a homozygous mutation (E143del) in the CYP24A1 gene.
